# Arpeggio: 9th in G (Shape: C)

An arpeggio is the notes of a chord played individually in a sequence. The 9th arpeggio in G using the shape of a C chord utilizes the notes G-B-D-F-A. In this case, the 9th note (A) is added to the standard G major triad (G-B-D) along with the 7th (F), creating an extended harmony.

## Notes and Intervals:
- G (root)
- B (major third)
- D (perfect fifth)
- F (minor seventh)
- A (major ninth)

## Genre and Musical Flavor:
This arpeggio adds color and tension to the standard G major chord. It is often used in jazz, fusion, and other genres where extended harmonies are prevalent. The 9th arpeggio in G (Shape: C) introduces a sense of sophistication and complexity to the music, creating a lush and contemporary sound.

## Songs:
1. **"So What" by Miles Davis**: In this iconic jazz composition, the G9 arpeggio is often used in improvisational sections to add depth and interest to the chord progressions.
   
2. **"Cantaloupe Island" by Herbie Hancock**: This jazz standard features the G9 arpeggio in different sections of the song, showcasing its versatility and melodic potential.

3. **"Spain" by Chick Corea**: This jazz fusion masterpiece incorporates the G9 arpeggio in various sections, highlighting its harmonic richness and expressive capabilities.
